step1.sentence: The manager nodded and told the team to go ahead with the new design plan.

step2.story: Lily hesitated before asking her question, worried it might sound silly. Her teacher smiled and encouraged her to go ahead, reminding everyone that there are no bad questions. So she asked it, and three other students nodded along.

step3.story: The city council had been debating the new park project for two years. Residents showed up at every meeting to voice their support. Finally, the council voted to go ahead with the plan. Workers broke ground the following week, and children from nearby schools came to watch the first shovel go into the ground.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 허락이나 확인을 받아 일을 진행하다; 상대에게 먼저 하도록 권하다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 승인 후 일을 시작하거나 계속할 때, 또는 상대방에게 먼저 하라고 권할 때 씁니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: go(가다)와 ahead(앞으로)가 결합하여 앞으로 나아가다, 즉 진행하다라는 의미가 되었습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 허락을 주거나 받는 상황 모두에 씁니다. Go ahead는 어서 해요 또는 먼저 하세요로 씁니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: We got the green light, so let's go ahead and start the project.
